posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524651
>So why are the mosfets blowing up?

that's for you to determine using your vast experience and collection of instruments.
if you experience is vastly non-existent, you might consider a divide-and-conquer strategy.
i.e. isolating parts of the circuit to see what *stops* the FETs from dying.
you might start with the rectifier diodes, seems there's 8 of them.
disconnect one leg on each of them, then run a test.
if nothing died, try adding an appropriate load after the disconnected diodes, maybe some 12V lamps between an anode and cathode in the same 4-diode set.
if all went well, put back the diodes but cut traces or remove components to isolate other parts.
continue until you find the culprit (or you've destroyed the board, or destroyed your sanity)

one trick you might try is to put a 120V 60W lamp in series with the power input to reduce max current.
this might keep the FETs alive longer.
google for more info.

Yes and no. You should be able to just solder wires onto pads part of the same node, or scratch the solder mask to make new pads. May not be an option if those mounting holes are also mechanical though, looks a bit like a computer mouse's switch footprint, but even in that instance you can epoxy the new switch to the board and run short jumper wires from its pins.

Gotta be real careful with FR2, the paper/phenolic substrate delaminates much more easily than glass/epoxy. Moderate temperature, a bit of extra flux on the board, a bit of liquid solder on the tip, and only keeping the iron on the board for 3s or so before letting it cool down.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524978
Chances are you can feed an RF input to the antenna port like you had to with old TVs, for which you just feed a normal composite video signal into an RF modulator (>>2524989). Kinda a hack, but it's the most authentic. If you're modding it anyway, it should be possible to add a switch after the RF demodulation for a normal composite video input. Converting VGA to composite is somewhat easy, doubly so if that's a greyscale TV, but if it is colour there may well be a section past the composite-to-colour decoder circuit to inject RGB signals that could come from VGA with none/some modification.
>digital
On your own for that. I'd just bodge a decoder chip in there, preferably one set to output at the right resolution. Maybe just the internals of a common converter box if that happens to work properly.

By switch I mean a diode switch or some other impedance-respecting RF gate. That kind of signal injection may be kinda hacky as a modification to the existing PCB, so if you're in the game of making PCBs I'd definitely consider reverse engineering the video decoding PCB to make a new one with the switch built-in. If you live somewhere like I do with no analogue TV anyhow, you may consider desoldering some components in series with the composite video signal and replacing them with a custom board on pin-headers, or just wires going directly to a composite video socket.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524998
What matters more is the power dissipation. What voltage will be across each transistor? P = I*V, so if it's 12V then it's 6V on each transistor, and so 12W dissipated in a transistor worst case. You can probably derate that depending on situation. 2A is a bit much for a BD139/BD140, so I guess I'd use something like a TIP31/32. The minimum hFE of them is 10, so that's 200mA out of the op-amp, which is kinda high. May want to consider using a sziklai or darlington setup (choose whatever lets you common the tabs together on the heat-sink), or finding power BJTs with higher current gain.
Then you'd need the heat-sinking to handle that power. For ∆T=50C, you'd want 50/12 = 4.2C/W, and the transistor clamp thermal resistance is 1.7C/W, which means a somewhat large heat-sink of 2.5C/W. The TO-220 package has a resistance to ambient of 57C/W, for reference. Can maybe run it a bit hotter than that, and derate the power dissipation based off required current output waveform. Each transistor will only heat half of that if the average current is 0, but if both are strapped to the heat-sink it's the same required thermal resistance. Divide that 1.7C/W by 2 if it's even.
Naturally, use your own PSU voltage.

Also watch out for crossover distortion when the current goes from positive to negative, I'd want to use a high-slew-rate op-amp if not turn that into a class-AB topology instead of a class-B. Or just use a power amplifier IC. A big output cap or two would likely help a lot. Actually big enough output caps would buffer the current so it wouldn't have to come from the transistors. Which is why single-ended speakers on single-supply rails usually just sink the other side of the speaker to the negative rail with a DC-blocking cap. Split-rail supplies or differential-output amps are popular to avoid such big caps, and they also work for net-DC signals.

>>2525401
SIPO shift register (e.g. 74HC165) like the other anon mentioned is one way, but I'd recommend going for a conventional key matrix. With a matrix you can split the pins in half and multiply them as rows and columns. For example, if you have 32 pins to spare, you'd split that into 16 rows and 16 columns, allowing for 16x16 buttons = 256 buttons. This is what computer keyboards do. Use a diode on each one if you want N-key rollover.

>>2525438
I'd also check out that diode or whatever next to the trimpots, the one with the darker area of PCB around it. That darker area suggests nontrivial heat production, that component may be the cause of the original fault, or perhaps it's just running close to its thermal limit by design. Either way I'd want to replace it with a better part. There's also the possibility that it overheated as a symptom of damage to other parts (maybe the trimpots, maybe something else), in which case replacing it may not fix all your problems, but it's probably worth doing anyhow.

>It's a 12v 1w zener
Ah, then chances are it's running normally. Zeners are often left running rather hot, and it shouldn't be bad for the zener, but judging by the surrounding PCB's discolouration it's quite possible that it could reduce the lifespan of nearby components (like the trimpot).

It's possible that you can replace the zener with a TL431 circuit (with additional PNP shunt transistor), which is arguably easier to find. TL431s are somewhat common in isolated SMPS designs, so chances are you may have some on scrap boards already.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525563
>16 to 1
Those exist? I've only seen 8-to-1.

Also just reading off a PISO is basically the same as cycling through each value. Can kinda use SPI hardware to take the load off your MCU, even better if you can use USART hardware's extra pins to output a clock AND toggle the CTS or whatever pin in order to latch the register. DMA or maybe an event system could streamline that data path further.
Personally i'd recommend using entire I/O ports for parallel data inputs (e.g. keyb matrix), so you can do direct port reads for quick data inputs. You could combine these by using SIPO shift registers to drive the rows, and PISO shift registers to read the columns. This kind of circuit would be useful for something with hundreds of pins needed to be mapped, like an LED cube.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525598
>What do you mean by AC current?
capacitors alone can buffer an ac current output, since it's kinda a voltage divider using capacitive impedance Z_C = 1/(2πf*C). If f=0, then the impedance is high, and so it can't provide any current. If f is high enough that Z_C is much lower than the speaker impedance, then it acts close to an ideal ground rail.
>I want to power a chip amp requiring symmetrical power source using a DC jack
You can also just use two (at least one of them ungrounded) PSUs in series to give yourself a middle rail. That said, I'd avoid any switching power supply for noise reasons, unless you're adding your own nice discrete transistor pass regulators and/or LC filters. If your barrel-jack PSUs are not switching, then they've got an iron transformer that you can disassemble and wire like your picrel anyhow, they might even have multiple output taps anyhow.
>zener
There's no zener there. Just a Schottky reverse polarity diode and an LED. The two resistors are a requirement, and the caps need to be big enough to have minimal ripple voltage at the desired current. Too small caps and you'll lose bass.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525591
i can see what youre saying. but combining SIPO and PISO for row column access is the wasting the same amount of clock cycles anyway, or possibly more. also, OP said he needs to be able to read everything simultaneously. the problem with modt keyb matrices is that you cant do this. you can only read the buttons in that row. with chaining big PISOs together, you may be reading all of them sequentially, but ALL buttons can be active at once and still be read correctly.

you could use spi hardware or just designate the gpio as 'very fast' in its config and use timer interrupts. additionally you could attach the clock pin to multiple PISO chains attached to say 8pins and on every clock cycle do a full port register read which should give you all the pin states at once. allowing you to read in 8 buttons at a time on every clock cycle. theres many other ways of doing a keyb matrix, but thats my take

see pic rel for basic idea that applies to all pieces I made. I dunno how you would print that. Gonna paste my an explanation

It consists of a backer plate (9 light + 9 heavy layers), porcelain shards and a topper (3 +3) encasing the ceramics. Wanted to use 2 offset layers of ceramics, instead I placed the first and additional shards on what I deemed crucial parts of the armor.

This is the basic method for all armor parts I made, a full plate with porcelain for my mask, forearms and torso, the rest consists only of the backer type plate, 18 layers of sandwiched light and heavy glass cloth.

Made a visor from 1cm thick polycarbonat. Went trough some trial and error while attempting to heat bend it. Made a bubble free curved piece with our oven, the trick is to heat it up to 150c first and frequently open the door to let out steam, after a while turn it up to 175c. I want to thank thermoplastic anon for that info again. Another thanks to soap bar anon, scrub a bar of soap then wipe with a dry towel on glassy surfaces like glasses you don't want to fog up with your breath, it really works.

show examples of how this could be made, 3d printers are definetevly cool, but I noticed a trend where people will simply assume that a printer can print anything. How would you measure out your face this way? I did with simple gypsum bandages. And then print it how? Carbon fibres? For costs, a 33cm x 33cm rectangle plate costs about 15€ in material costs, the groin plate has this size. thats 9 + 9 patches of the heavy a d light glass filament. 1m2 can be cut into 9 patches. 1m2 of glass weave costs about 3-5€, so about 3 for the light and 5 for the heavy, 8€ total for the weave. Epoxy resin can be expensive, cheapest I found was 11€ per kg. for a 33cmx33cm plate with 18 layers of mixed weaves I needed 750g of epoxy, so about 7-9€ or something. Now you got a basic plate for what 15-20€. Porcelain is the best worst ceramic for balistic protection, you can source that for free. Add another glass weave for spalling protection above that to stop porcelain fragments from flying everywhere and boom you got a decent plate I'd say. 25€ max.

the protective gear part is a different beast. the orthopaedic gear is to prevent knee injury from missteps or non optimal posture. same goes for the lumbar belt.
even the cheap aldi versions do their job.

joint injury is the number one eliminator of modern troops.

for the fit: add a padded comfortable belt strap with some semi-rigid plate support. this way you circumvent the spine being loaded and free your lungs more. putting padding on the shin lower side, so it rests better on the shoe, can make the bug a feature.

some light knee pads could help with the armor and hard knuckle or sand gloves would add some necessary hand protection.

for the groin plate: try to cut it int an inverted trapezoid (basicly upside down chest plate shape). then it moves more easily when walking. the two removed pieces can be added as belt flaps/ armor skirt pieces.

>>2513688
For maximum efficiency, cut the fat out and chop it into ~1cm cubes. Put it in a pot with some water to cover and heat it to a simmer. After a few hours all the fatty acids will be rendered out of the tissue, then you sift the chunks out and let the liquids harden. The fat layer separates and floats on the water. To clean it just scrape the grimy bits off the bottom of the solid fat layer and put it back in a pot with fresh water and a generous handful of salt, bring it to a simmer and stir it a bit, let it cool and repeat until pearly white. Finally melt the fat down and insert a wick. There you go, odorless human candle.
Human fat is about 7700kcal/kg which is a lot better than wood pellets which generally sit around 4300kcal/kg. You only need a small fraction of that energy to refine it.

To make soap all you need to do is weigh your human tallow, then bring it to about 50°C. Take 26.82% of your fat weight in distilled water and 13.41% in pure lye and dissolve it in the water (do it with good ventilation or die). It will heat to almost boiling so let the mixture come down to around 50°C also, then dump it in the liquid fat and blend it with an immersion blender until it turns into a sort of paste. Scoop that out into whatever mold you like and let it sit for a day, then demold it and let it air dry for 2-4 weeks.

I wrote ZNA productions and techthisoutmeow multiple times, donated to their patreon. Wanted them to build and shoot test panels with my method. Mentioning it again, 9 light + 9 heavy layers and additionally porcelain + another 3 heavy and 3 light ontop. No further responses for about two months or so.

But thankfully a german hansguns offered to test it for me, I'll be sending him 2 such testpanels after xmas. I've gained some doubts of the success of my plates delivering what I hope for, because I did something different. I didn't vacuum press the plates during curing. My theory is, the epoxy itself should stay where it is and not be pressed out excessively. Further, I think a pressed conventional plate has it disadvantages too. The layers are already then pressed together and it' s maybe easier to penetrate them this way.

Only live tests will show if my theoretical method has advantages over singular type of weave pressed plates. If I had something like military interest funding, I'd research this matter more troughly, but I'm a literal neet lmao.

So I actually made a plate like this when I was a teenager. I took a piece of polycarbonate, placed ceramic tiles on top and then laminated the whole thing with many layers of fiberglass and polyester resin. Then I went to a gunfag board and asked some one to shoot it for me.

The results were not good, basically the only thing that didn't penetrate fully was .22LR. I don't remember exactly what he shot it with but I recovered the jacket of a large caliber pistol, possibly 45ACP and a small rifle round, most likely .223. Simply put, ceramic tiles are not hard enough to stop rifle rounds and while they may be able to fragment pistol rounds, they then turn into shrapnel that blows right through the backing. The whole thing was too stiff to work even as 3A armor and while polycarbonate is very tough, it cannot withstand the high impulse of a bullet impact, it basically tore open like a flap and let everything through.

posts.sub: Homemade Cross-Country Ski Bindings, Wax, and Poles
posts.com:
Cross-posting from /out/ for /diy/ wisdom.
Cheers, anons.
I'm a poorfag, so the only skis I found this winter were ones at the local thrift store, for $20.

Unfortunately, they didn't come with bindings nor boots, and the only ones I found with bindings were old-school 3-pin ones - which would be great, except I could not find any boots in my size over a 2 week period, and delivery would've taken a month and a half, from China.

As such, I've decided to construct my own cross-country ski bindings, with the advantage of being able to use any boots I want.
Since I won't be competing or doing alpine-touring runs downhill at 40mph, I figured I didn't need bindings that are 100% reliable.

Here are my experiments so far.
We had beautiful ski weather a few days ago, which made me pretty desperate to get outside and ride a bit.
I went and attached some steel L-brackets I had, and then used paracord to strap my feet in.
Needless to say, it didn't work out very well - although I got the heel of my boot to go up and down freely, there was far too much side-to-side play - almost sprained my ankle.

Was defeated for the rest of the day, which was mostly spent thinking about how to solve the problem of side-to-side movement.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Next day, I went to the hardware store, bought some door hinges, as I saw recommended in a homemade-snow-shoe-binding-into-cross-country-ski-bindings retrofitting article.
I elected to use a narrow wooden plank as a base to which to attach the boot, to avoid side-to-side play.

Drilled out holes in the wood, and passed the same paracord through them, which held much better thanks to the "foundation" provided by the wood - I wove together a harness for my boot, and it held pretty well.
This worked a lot better, and I made it about 300 feet before they loosened up and fell apart, leading to yet another fall.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I am currently at a crossroads - should I use zip-ties to create the binding for the front-end of my boot, and then a rag, spun into rope, to hold the back of the boot?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The thin paracord really dug into my foot - a solution I found was using dog collars, but for some reason, they're expensive as shit here.
I'm thinking that the rag would spread the pressure nicely over a larger surface area, and the zip-ties would be a very sturdy holder for the tips of the boots.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I also need to make my own kick and glide waxes - for this, I've found a paraffin candle works great as far as the glide wax is concerned.
I am also in the process of finding a grip wax - I would like ideally to make my own pine tar, but for the time being, I'm finding that soft black licorice, rubbed over the kick zone, provides an excellent - the sugars + waxy nature of the candy glides very well over snow, but have an excellent "bite" to grip with, especially once it cools.
Using only one piece of licorice, I covered the bases of both skis.

To make the poles, I cut down a 3 year old maple tree (I have many on the property, and it's part of forest management best practice anyways.)

Thanks for sharing mate!
What your dad had was exactly what I'm trying to make - those bindings were extremely popular in Europe (and all over the world) during a time when skiing was seen as a means of getting around - I am taking the design off of what they use in Russia and Finland, and there was also a mountaineering army unit in the United States which used regular military boots with "universal" bindings.

They just don't manufacture them anymore - in the places where people live innawoods, they just make their own, and in the places where people ski recreationally, it's all consumables which start at $300, minimum.

I really think I could make a quality universal binding for under $100. But, I don't want to get too ambitious - I will try to make a nice binding from zip-ties at the front, and an anon on /out/ advised me to use leather belts - which was a great idea, I forgot they exist. So for the heel, I'll cut a metal can in half, and then tie a leather belt around the wooden piece (maybe chisel out a channel for the belt.)

I will make sure to post updates!
And again, thank you, anon!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Updates.
I decided to make the second version of the bindings today.
Tomorrow's a big snowstorm, and I'd like to take them out for a spin.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
To explain what I did - I decided that part of the reason why paracord held so poorly was because it's very difficult to tie it into a good knot.

I had a 50 pack of microfiber rags, and chose to sacrifice one of them for the straps I'll use to anchor my boot in - after getting them wet (to make sure they don't fall apart), I knotted/spun them into ropes, and then double-spun them again, to make a 2-stranded rope which I then passed through freshly drilled holes in the wooden platform.

The zip-tie holds the toe of the boot down, and is where most of the forces will be applied - the two most critical components are the heel strap and the toe "pocket", which is why I think I'll add a second set of zip-ties and straps to both.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2522873
A reasonably good quality jigsaw can do it, use a narrow scroll blade for tight curves and a wider one for straight cuts to avoid it taking off at an angle...longer straight cuts can be roughed in in the middle with a circular saw and the ends of blind cuts finished with the jigsaw for the same reason.
The other option would be to make a template of the repeating shape and use a router with a straight bit and a guide collar.
Personally I'd use the saw for that number since it's quick and easy and any small deviations will just make it look more period authentic ...too perfect can stick out and look weird.
Just be methodical, cut every incidence of one hole shape or curve in one operation then move to the next group rather than starting at one end and working in a line; it will be more uniform and of one piece and minimizes forgetting some detail until someone notices when its up on the building.

>>2522886
Also when you get into tighter curves and inside corners turn off any orbital feature so the blade is cutting straight up and down like a scroll saw.
Most scroll blades for jigsaws are set up this way but double check all the blades you use to make sure the teeth are oriented to cut on the upstroke which also has keep them from wandering off track.
Depending on the material and shapes you can also sometimes use hole saws to locate and reproduce curves and then connect the dots between them saving time and risk of broken jigsaw blades.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2523025
>pressure treated

PT is for ground contact, makes no sense here.
Cypress is the preferred timber species for that kind of exterior trim and has the best mix of even grain structure, dimensional stability and pest/rot resistance for exterior trim. Cedar is another alternative.
Common fir/ hemlock construction lumber with alternating hard/soft grain is a nightmare to try to make this kind of scrolling detail in, and is also more likely to warp and crack across short cross grain details.
If you can't do the cost of cypress or cedar, spruce and pine work too.
Regardless of what gets used, prime and paint every square inch of it prior to installation; nailing it up raw and just painting the faces/edges is a recipe for cupping and warping and snapping off details.
If you want to treat it with something like cuprinol, after cutting it is the time to do it.

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2500970
Like the name suggests, the mash pot is the steel pot in which you heat up your water+grains.
Sparge water is pre-heated water that you use to rinse off the grains after taking them out. So when your mashing ends and you lift your mash-basket / brew bag to let it drain, there's still a lot of sugars attached to the wet grains. So you slowly rinse the grains with the hot sparging water to wash out the remaining sugars. The magic behind it is to use as much water as necessary but as less water as possible, because if you use too much water, you're lowering your OG again.

>The OG is off at first and then I add water until it falls within the range (which is what the instructions say). But that never brings it up to more than 4.5 gallons and sometimes it's barely 4 gallons.
That means that your brewhouse efficiency is too low, so either you're doing something wrong while mashing, or the grains in the brew kits are of low quality.
If you're mashing at a too low temperature, the alpha and beta amylases don't have enough time to convert the starches into sugars, if your mashing temperature is too high, the amylases create a lot of unfermentable sugars.
What is your brew set-up? Do you use an automatic electric brew-kettle, or a diy solution? Do you use the iodine test at the end of mashing to check on remaining starches?

posts.name: CEO of Yeast Nutrients
posts.com:
>>2501480
In a normal batch of mead or fruitwine, without nutrients, over 50% of the pitched yeast is dead after 3 days. That's absolutely normal as the apoptosis of the yeast will serve as a nutrient-dispenser for the younger yeast generation. After that the amount of live yeast will drop exponentially.
With yeast nutrients the same amount of dead yeast is only reached after 5 days, that's 2 more days of healthy sugar conversion at the time of highest activity after yeast-pitching. And what's the effort to get that? Like opening a bag and putting a teaspoon full of powder into your fermenter?
>If you go to work the next two days, you'll get double the pay
>Nah, fuck that, I'm too lazy. Also I never used that and my bank account has been fine

>but I subsequently read an article someone(you?) posted about yeast autolysis/apoptosis as a "scorched earth" way of feeding its own lineage while poisoning other strains of yeast.
Yeah, that was me. The apoptosis caused by "natural causes" (Which is still not fully understood scientifically) is a genetic program inside the yeast that tells it "You're old enough, time to die", so the yeast cell dies and decomposes into substances that work as nutrients for the other cells.
Only if the cause of death is not "natural", the apoptosis triggers the "Scorched Earth" mode and the cell decomposes into the different toxic proteins.
Fact is, that in most cases a stuck fermentation is caused by missing yeast nutrients.

posts.name: CEO of Yeast Nutrients
posts.com:
>>2501686
It won't be the next Amateur Brew-Off Champion but it'll be a challenge to get the best out of nothing.

>Diastatic Malt
Diastatic means that it contains active enzymes which are able to convert the starches into sugars. That means you'll definitely get a wort out of this.
My definite recommendation would be to closely keep to the resting times:
Protease Resting: 10-20 min. @54°C (Proteins will be broken down to create free amino nitrogens which work as yeast nutrients)
Maltose Resting: 30-90 min. @62°C (Polysaccharides will be broken down into maltose by beta-amylase, that's your source for fermentable sugar)
Mashout: 15-45 min. @71°C (Polysaccharides will be broken down into dextrin by alpha-amylase which will bring aroma, flavor and mouth-feeling)
I'd especially recommend the mashout, since we don't know what kind of flavor your malt will bring into the game. Make sure that your brewing setup is capable of raising the temperature at least 1°C per minute to ensure fast switches between the rests. And don't omit the Protease Rest, as the CEO of Yeast Nutrients I'll know if you do.

>Distillers yeast
Don't use that, get some bakers yeast instead. Distillers yeast is especially bred for really high alcohol tolerances (18-21%ABV) without regards for losses, which especially shows in aroma and flavor, most mashes with distillers yeast have no proper flavor at all.

>Cheapest hop brand hops
We can figure something out with this, as long as you know the alpha-acid contents of your hops.
You need to define first what kind of beer you're aiming for, how many IBUs, how much hops in the flavor and how much in the aroma. Smell your hops and see for yourself if you want that aroma in your beer. If not, then you should omit late additions. If you're boiling for 60 minutes and you want bitterness and flavor, then add @60 mins. and @30 mins. Make sure that you measure the amounts properly and remember that the total amount will decide about the final IBUs.

>>2502932
I don’t think cold crashing alone will solve that, it doesn’t kill or filter all living yeasts. Pasteurise or k meta or wait for sugar to run out. My experience with sorbate isn’t too good either btw. As in I put 4x the recommended dose once and still had live yeast left.

Pasteurisation is really easy if its in bottles already. Put a coaster in a big pan, put bottles in, and 1 bottle of water. Top pan up with hot water, put thermometer in water bottle, turn on stove, wait for desired temperature + duration. Doesn’t affect taste if you stay under 80C/175F. The coaster prevents the glass from touching the pan which could overheat the bottom.

Anyway for cold crashing just put fridge on low setting and leave bottles in overnight

Is it really fermenting or is it just releasing all the CO2 that was previously solved in solution?

posts.name: CEO of Yeast Nutrients

>>2503511
What will be the main thing you'll brew with it?
A lot of people make a fetish out of temperature control, in my opinion that's only necessary in specialty beers (e.g. Saison) and if you have not a single place on hand with a stable temperature environment.
If you have a cellar or basement with a constant temperature in the operating range of your yeast, you won't need temperature control on your fermenter.
In the end it's a nice to have but not something I'd waste 600 bucks for.
Just as a comparison, the 30 liter stainless steel fermenter from Brew Monk has a port for temperature probe (Probe with digital thermometer pre-installed), only costs 199.95€ and you can even get a chiller for that fermenter for 89.95€.
Those of course don't offer the functionality of being a keg and a fermenter in one, but for the money you saved, you can get 3 normal kegs on top.

>>2514161
Measuring the specific gravity should help you know when the yeast are about spent and not liking the alcohol solution strength anymore. If it stops going down then they aren't using the sugar additions. If you can get your hands on some sorbate or something like that you should be able to shut them down pretty good. Sugar on its own is a preservative and can give germs and shit a hard time.
If alcohol is ill eagle in a country and someone is home brewing to get around that they might as well go all the way and distill. Doesn't even have to be fancy. Any home canner or pressure cooker is readily converted to churn out some kind of spirit and if you're even a little handy brazing ain't too hard. In the US we can try bluffing and say it's all for beer if caught and they'll probably drop it. I don't know of any good excuses for possessing equipment like this if muh beer isn't an option.
As for getting a lot of yeast when transferring I think you need a second vessel. Transfer from first bucket to second once fermentation has decreased activity. In this second vessel the yeast should fall out and will yield clearer bottles. If you're made of money you can always find a way to run it through a filter. I don't know how to go about doing this without a keg to pressurize and push the solution through it. There must be some kind of way to use gravity without too much oxygen exposure though. Still, at that point it's easiest to just rack to a second or even third bucket with time in between for yeasties to drop down to the bottom.

>>2516001
> Does gray mold damage ceramics?
Depends, if it’s intact glazed ceramics then no but a lot can happen if something finds it’s way into small cracks or under the glazing

> Additionally, is cleaning the mold out and wiping with soap and vinegar enough?
No

> Or does it require some speshul ritualistic cleansing
Yes. Mold spores are very resilient and vinegar may not reach all of them inside small cracks or scratches. You could boil them out at 90C but have to be sure that the ceramic is heated through and through. Quaternary ammonium cation is a common spore killer but works by leaving a small reactive film that will probably kill yeasts too. Would probably use heat as it’s the only thing that you can be sure reaches every spot, but it may not even be worth it if it’s a cheap old scratched jar

posts.com:
>>2516195
>Reminded me a bit of how mae homemade Glögg
Glögg is just a fortified mulled wine, no fermentation involved.

Looking at the ingredients it indeed sounds like a really intense spicy/earthy brew which could use a higher alcohol content.

But this anon >>2515733 is correct, you'll end up with about 860g sugar per liter which is enough to create about 44% ABV if the average yeast wouldn't die under the osmotic pressure of 420g sugar per liter or around 22% ABV. (Or even sooner, depending on strain)

With 250 - 280g sugar per liter you'll reach 12.8 - 14.3% ABV and the osmotic pressure is low.
So you should use 875 - 980g sugar in total for your brew.

Just remember the basics:
>Sanitize your equipment
>Use an airlock
>Give it time (12.8 - 14.3% ABV can take 4-6 weeks to dry fermentation)

>>2516720
Low tech recipe:
Blend apples with 1tbsp of water per apple. I use a kitchen blender. Strain through cheesecloth, keep pulp in juice to a minimum. Add sugar or preservative free honey (if needed) while heating. You get ≈5% abv from the apple juice plus ≈1% per 20g/L of added sugar. Don’t cook it, but pasteurise. Let it cool to room temp and let yeast warm to room temp. Put juice in carboy, add a few tsp yeast on top, close carboy but not air tight (or preferably, with airlock) and let sit. Wait 2-4 weeks or so until no more bubbles appear, then 1 more. Siphon into clean carboy/bottles, wait two weeks, siphon again. If there’s a residue at the bottom, repeat once more. Taste will slowly get better from around 5 weeks after first siphoning.

Most important keep everything sterile/sanitised. Carboy, tools, funnels, hoses, bottles, airlock etc. Boiling water works most of the time, Star San is better and doesn’t burn your hands. Use brewers yeast not bread yeast.

>>2518235
> it should foam for like a week, but it's only the second day and the foam on mine is completely gone
Foam is mostly initial stages when yeast is growing very fast. Depends on nutrients how long foam lasts, shorter/longer may be a good or a bad sign. If sugar is very low, foaming is more visible than with high sugar. I usually get between 2 and 5 days.

> There's no sediment or visible layers so far. Is it fine or is it bad?
Did you put enough yeast? The yeast grows, the healthy yeast get suspended/float up and down. The dead yeast stay at the bottom as sediment. If the yeast can’t grow for some reason, you’ll only have very little of it

> It still bubbles good through the airlock and has a decent and fairly strong fruity wine smell
As long as it’s bubbling, it’s fermenting. But it may take longer if your yeast isn’t in great shape.

posts.name: CEO of Yeast Nutrients
posts.com:
>>2517336
>>2517416
Your "personal experience" and your White Labs fart smelling kit doesn't prove shit.
Bakers yeast is Saccharomyces, exactly as brewers yeast, wine yeast or distillery yeast and it will perform just great with alcohol tolerances up to 12 %ABV depending on manufacturer. (e.g. Dr. Oetker in Germany and surrounding countries, Fleischmann in the US and Canada) The main part in flavoring the
>Beer
is the malt
>Wine
is the fruit/honey
while the yeast contributes nothing more than a "direction" the flavor takes, a kind of signature finger-snapping. Let's just make ye olde English Brown Ale with bakers yeast for the sake of it:
Will it have exactly that distinct, classic Brown Ale flavor? No, very most liekely not.
Will it taste like a good and proper dark beer? Hell yes, it will, because the malt will already contribute 90% of the flavor.
The only distinction that I allow in this discussion is that bakers yeast tends to not settle into a compact sediment-cake at the bottom after fermentation is done but will stay in a loosely, floaty state at the bottom of the fermenter, but that has nothing to do with the flavor.

Fun fact: Most breweries fucking 1000 years ago in the Germanic/Bohemian regions got their yeast from surrounding bakeries. Specialty yeasts just became a thing when brewers started to breed their yeasts to save on cost only later they realized that their yeast strain gave their beer that signature flavor. Was it proper beer before they reached their signature flavor? Yes it was.

posts.name: CEO of Yeast Nutrients
posts.com:
>>2521220
Distillers yeast is Saccharomyces, so it works as well as all other yeast strains when it comes to creating alcohol.
But one thing that strains declared as distillers yeast have in common is, that they are bred for maximum alcohol tolerance without regards to losses, which makes them a really bland strain. They don't create any special aromas and no distinct flavor profile.
If that's what you're after, then it's perfectly fine to continue to use them. If you're trying to create a certain flavor profile, or you want to increase the amount of Glycerin produced, then you should start to try out some other strains.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2520523
>also my kitchen scale is only accurate to 1 gram so if i lost 3 grams that might actually be 2,6 or 3,4 grams
Btw resolution and accuracy/repeatability is not the same. Cheap digital kitchen scales will easily give you a few grams difference depending on which side you put the weight on and how flat your table is, there's also temperature drift and god knows what else. Professional lab scales are routinely calibrated with standard weights and use thermally stabilized circuitry to achieve their accuracy, which you won't find in battery powered kitchen scales. I test mine regularly with a 2kg weight and they give me results different by like 5 grams throughout the week even though repeated measurements side by side are within 1 gram usually. You really want scales with 0.1g or better precision if you want to hunt down single grams accurately.

Cider coming fresh out of fermentation tastes "green", I guess that's what you're tasting without really knowing how to put it into words.

Cider needs time, add 8g of sugar per liter (if you want it carbonated), bottle it and let it rest in a dark and moderately cool place for at least 3 months and try again.
Also, try to get an acidometer kit (Not a pH kit, that's something completely different) to calculate the acidity of your cider, it might simply be too high. In that case it can help to start a malolactic fermentation before bottling.

That’s true, you’ll see the bubbles, and when they stop you’re out of sugar or reached alcohol tolerance (or stuck). Speed of fermentation is a science on its own and depends on too many factors to describe here. Most stuff over 10 brix will start in 2-48 hours and finish in 7-21 days

> unless it doesn't or something bad takes over first
If you keep everything sanitised and keep air out as much as you can (ie airlock or at least keep it mostly covered) chances of infection are slim. There’s little shit that can out compete yeasts in sugar at low oxygen after the first 24 hours

posts.name: CEO of Yeast Nutrients
posts.com:
>>2521620
>Found chead honey from a restaurant site is that good or just poor quality
No chance for us to know. Like this anon >>2521675 suggested, you should read the ingredients and decide from there.

>And was hoping to get 15% abv what best yeast and or additives needed to get a around that
The alcohol tolerance of the yeast doesn't tell you how much ABV you'll get, you'll also need the sugar-content to back it up. If you don't have enough sugar in your brew, you won't reach 15%, no matter the yeast. For 15% ABV you'll need around 290g sugar per liter. Depending on quality and time of the year, honey can have around 80g - 90g sugar per 100g honey, so 300g honey per liter is what you'd want to use. As for additives, you'd need yeast nutrients, since honey is very low in nutrients that yeast can use, also you need to shake in a lot of air before pitching the yeast. If the brew creates a strong sulfuric smell in the first 3-4 days, it was not enough oxygen. A very slight sulfuric smell is OK.

>Also do I need a hydrometer?
I'd like to refer to my earlier post here >>2519799
It's not a necessity, but it's somewhat useful to control your process and to go from turning great honey into a shitty product to turning great honey into a great product. Even a cheap, inaccurate hydrometer will do, since the hydrometer is in essence not a tool that delivers an accurate value of X in a single measurement. It's rather a tool to measure differences and change over time. If your hydrometer is cheap and inaccurate, you might not be able to accurately calculate your ABV and you might be off by +/- 1%, but what it can do is track a value of X today and a value of <X next week which tells you that fermentation is still ongoing and it's too soon to bottle.

>Is there a recommended recipe with more exact amounts that can be split or doubled as needed?
There is a ton out there. If you're more the video learning type, try City Steading Brews
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y0W7K5yBK-g

posts.name: CEO of Yeast Nutrients
posts.com:
>>2522219
>but the acidity still hits you in the aftertaste.
Acidity is something relative.
If you split your brew into three batches, they all have the same acidity. If you do the following:
>Add sugar to the first
>Age the second for 4 months
>Carbonate the third
then all three brews will taste as if they had different acidity.
Sugar will immediately lower the perceived acidity by a lot, that's especially observed in fruit wines like blackberry wine. Completely dry fermented blackberry wine is basically undrinkable but with the tiniest amount of sugar it suddenly becomes delicious.
Age will reduce perceived and real acidity as well, as seen in almost all fruit and honey wines.
Carbon-dioxide solved in water is an acid but for some reason carbon-dioxide reduces the perceived acidity in ciders and sparkling fruit wines. I have no scientific paper to back this up, it is based solely on my observation and taste over the years.

>any details on the MLF?
So I do primary in bucket, secondary in carboy and then some more in an oak barrel with a tap. There are two ways to suss out when it's done.
As it does its thing it also makes co2 so it will slightly pressurize the must even when the yeast is tapped out. You can bleed the barrel a bit without opening the bung and introducing too much oxygen. So you either go by taste or when it gets to the point where the pressure won't force the liquid out with an unopened bung.

>Still got a question about EC1118 though, the package says to let it rehydrate at 35-37C, however I learned you shouldn’t change temperature of yeast quickly to prevent stress. Am I supposed to slowly heat the dry yeast from room temp to 35C before I let it rehydrate?
The temperature change issue is more of a thing after the yeast wakes up, it basically alters how dirty the byproducts get. Conceptually, it's like "rolling coal" in a diesel engine, if it's running too hot you'll get fuels and congeners. If you chill it too quickly it flocs out.
All that said, I usually pitch it right into must.

>>2523785
if it's not getting better than your pic related after polishing for an hour, then you're doing it wrong.

I would start with a lower grit, 320-400, then go stepwise through several finer grits until you do 3000. After the 3000 the epoxy will feel smooth as glass to the touch, but it will still be opaque/white.
Finally you use a polishing compound to bring it back to clear.

This is assuming of course that your epoxy is fully cured by now. Despite manufacturer claims, sometimes even when you measure and mix it appropriately, you wind up with resin that takes days or weeks to cure.

t. I've bought and used shitty chinese epoxy and polished it later

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2523144
>Anybody here make their own cigarettes? Is its easy?
Yeah, it's easy to use the tube stuffing type machines if you don't want to hand roll them.
It's probably faster to use the stuffing machine too. I used the "topomatic" type machine.
>Cheaper then manufactured ones?
It's way way fucking cheaper. Do the math; you can get a pound of decent tobacco for like 15$ and tubes to go with it for another 5$ and make about 20 packs of cigarettes.
It'll probably average you around a dollar per pack or less.

One problem with doing this though is that the cigarettes won't be exactly like your favorite store brand. They won't taste exactly the same because cigarette manufacturers use a proprietary blend of flavors and treatments that is responsible for the distinct taste of their cigs. You can still find plenty of good quality, cheap tobacco (menthol, light, regular, extra bold, etc) but it will never be an exact match for your favorite brand.
Another thing is that these homemade ones will always burn just slightly differently than the industrial ones. Industrially made cigarettes are (AFAIK) made from a specially prepared reconstituted tobacco paper rather than shredded leaves. They do this to make things easier for their treatment steps, but also to make the mix have a 100% consistent texture and consistency that helps avoid problems with their processing and packing machinery. When you buy the cheap bags of raw tobacco, it's just leaves that have been cut/shredded to a consistency which is appropriate for rolling or tube packing cigs. So sometimes you may have a tiny inconsistency or packing error and wind up with a small void or an end of the tube that doesn't pack completely.

After you get familiar with the perfect amount of leaf to load in the machines chamber by doing a couple dozen cigs, you'll start to avoid this issue for the most part.

All in all, it's super cheap and easy to do and I'm always amazed that more smokers don't RYO

God damn I hate tubes, they are disgusting and overpriced as a motherfucker.

Anyway, a non-shit machine won't blink at any size you throw at it, it should effectively make no difference.
The little plastic shooters and mid-range one handed bandits are pretty shit, they struggle with everything and aren't worth your time.

If you're going to pop out almost 2 cartons worth per week, you're going to want something that'll keep up.
If you practice, and you get good and quick with a Top-o-Matic style injector or a handheld plastic one, sit down and do it all very rapidly in one sitting without taking a brake, that'll take about an hour.
If you aren't a spastic twat, and also aren't a fucking master of the tube injector, you'll more realistically be spending 2+ hours per week making smokes.

A decent electric filler will save you so much time and effort it's worth joking about.
I have a hard time getting excited about 'em as I despise tubes and I'm probably faster with my rolling box (which isn't hand rolling, it's a fucking machine to do the work for you) than most faggots with a tube shooter.
If you want quantity though, a good electric filler is hard to beat.
It'll pay for itself anyway with the savings on smokes, and it'll pay for itself twice over versus the headaches of cheap shitty options.

Most out there are chinkanese, and some do actually suffer with longer tubes like you mentioned.
Handheld Plastic and Lever-Handle injectors are designed for specific sizes, and rarely perform well with any other size.
An electric that has adjustable pack/fill and has an oversized fill rod that can easily clear sizes beyond 100, that's what you want.
See if you have any local tobacco shops, as opposed to a smokeshop, decent chance they'll carry the same ones you find in the tobacco catalogs and you can actually get your eyes and hands on them instead of throwing darts online.

>>2524402
>The powdered stuff that you snort. Dont know the name, never tried it.
That's snuff, and it's fucking awesome.

Ozona is the most widespread brand in the US.
Their Presidential is pretty unimpressive in my opinion, the Weiss and English are much better.
The C-Type (cherry) is what I'd recommend to most first-timers as an introduction to the stuff.
You sniff a small amount, a very small amount, into your nostrils.
Just the nostrils, you're not inhaling it, just barely getting it up in there.

Of every tobacco product out there that I've tried, snuff is the closest analogue to cigarettes as far as the high they provide.
You use very, very little tobacco, and it hits you like a freight train, then wears off quickly.
It's convenient as hell, a little tin in your pocket is much smaller than a pack of smokes and won't be ruined by manhandling, and you can use it wherever the fuck because it sure as hell isn't smoke, and that includes wherever the kids with vapes aren't allowed.

Ever needed a smoke in the middle of an unimpressive movie you're sitting through with some bitch?
Ever really needed a smoke on a long flight?
Stuck in a meeting for a whole day with one fucking lunch break and no chance to take 5 and puff one?

Go buy a tin of snuff from any decent tobacco shop, usually costs less than a half-decent pack of smokes.
I'm a pack-a-day smoker, and if I'm on a business trip I won't bother with smokes, a 5g tin of snuff lasts me 5 days.
It may not replace your current preference, it sure as shit has never replaced cigarettes or cigars for me, but it is a fucking awesome addition to the line-up.

It's also worth noting, it's basically guaranteed to make you sneeze.
You get over it quickly if you use the stuff regularly, but your first few times it's pretty much a certainty that you'll sneeze some nasty tobacco-laden ectoplasm.
Be ready with a tissue the first time you try it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Power, Water, Heating, Cooling, Septic.
What's the best way to handle the big five off-grid?

>Power
Hydro is king, but flowing water is uncommon. Solar is weak and requires several parts that eventually need replacement. When power is abundant you get secondary systems for heating/cooling/etc. This one is hard.

>Water
Rainwater catchment? A water tower or attic water tank for gravity fed water? Maybe an underground cistern so it won't freeze, but then you lack gravity assistance.

>Heating
Can't beat wood. A secondary system should be in place, but a wood stove provides efficient heat and a cooking surface. Easy.

>Cooling
Hardest on the list. There is no simple wood stove-esque equivalent for cooling. Geothermal has promise but it's underpowered and expensive to install.

>Septic
Dead easy. You can put in your own tanks and outhouses just fine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2519243
Such vague answers, you must be specific in your utilization of say "wood". ie. A masonry stove? A normal metal wood stove? Also lacking here is the actual structure these will be used in, which plays the biggest roll in them succeeding.

As this anon said >>2519257
Site location and climate are the most important factors. If you have lots of sun, you will use sun, if you have a year round flowing river you could use a wheel for power.

In my climate, northern zone 5-6

>Power
Solar likely supplemented by some wind, the goal would be to reduce all other electrical uses and be very efficient.

>Water
Well would be easiest and cheapest vs. a buried cistern

>Heating
Masonry stove to supplement passive solar gains on a well insulated south facing structure along with proper roof overhands to stop summer sun.

>cooling
Solar protection via deciduous tree cover. In the winter I could absorb sunlight and in the summer be in the shade. Passive cooling can also be achieved via clever ventilation, ie. a black painted vent pipe high above my roof with some lower hanging windows opened. If I was built into a berm, I'd consider a ground pipe to pull cool underground air.

>Septic
Would depend on the number of people in the home. 2 people, I'd probably go with a composting toilet and call it a day. Grey water can go into a makeshift septic field without a proper poop tank.

>The important thing you left out - STRUCTURE
all these systems 100% work or fail based on the structure. You wont need a high thermal mass stove if you've build a cocoon of an insulated structure, since overheating will occur. My plan would be IDEALLY something like picrel, a bermed house facing south with an array of windows on that south face for winter gains. The roof would need to be angled to shade things out in summer. Structure would be concrete with some strong interior buttresses to hold back that buried rear wall. All concrete, foam, liner and dirt.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2519654
For the power bank, lead batteries are not recommended since they aren't meant to be repeatedly charged and discharged in such deep cycles. Lead batteries are better for emergencies, as a backup power source. Lithium batteries (there are many kinds) can be placed in parallel in order to form a power bank, but they are much more expensive and fragile. You would need to either constantly monitor the voltage and current of the batteries in order to avoid overcharging, drawing too much current, etc. There are systems you can buy for this, but they are expensive. Solar creates DC, but you would need a device to regulate the amount of charge it delivers to the battery to avoid overcharging. The wind turbine and Sterling engine create AC, which has to be converted to DC with a rectifier in order to charge the batteries (again, device needed to protect battery from overcharging). When you're ready to use your stored power, you need a power inverter to convert DC to AC so you may use it in your home. As for the bicycle, many people have used alternators to generate electricity, but once again, it creates an irregular AC signal which has to be converted to DC and then fed into a voltage regulator that can stabilize the output voltage and charge the batteries.

utmost important.

it's all about costs.
first, reduce power requirements to the bare minimum (no gaming pc or large tv, use a cheap laptop, etc).
then -and only then- budget for daily power usage (both summer and winter) and estimate battery requirements.
power bank: go for large LiFePo4 batteries (cost effective, safe, durable, futureproof)
diesel generator: only as an emergency backup

reduce water requirements to a reasonable minimum
consider enough storage for water bottles (you don't want to drink rain water that traversed your packed-with-birds-poop roof)

(in my country there are public taps all around; some people occasionally use them in the middle of the night to collect a few dozen gallons of water, taking a few hours of wait)

>Heating and Cooling
insulation will save both energy and headaches
can't beat wood...except if some Stacey complains about fumes
carefully design your kitchen, you don't want to sweat
also design for hot summer days, you don't want to regret about being unable to take advantage of wind and breeze

>Septic
tanks will fill up way faster than you may imagine. call a pro. won't be cheap
you will also need to switch to fully biodegradable cleaning products

>Extras
- design for maintainability
- mosquito nets and stuff

posts.com:
I live off grid, I wouldn't say there's a single best choice for each, it depends on your personal situation and having redundant systems is superior. This is my setup for what its worth
>Power
12kw solar panels into 2x 5kw inverters into a 3kw battery inverter with 15kwh of batteries, built this way to generate as much useable power in winter, at a cost of wasted peak production in summer.
I'd like to upgrade the battery inverter and batteries at some point
petrol generator
I'd like to add wind to the mix, but am not sure what size I should get or how I should wire it into the rest of the system
>Water
rainwater
springwater
either source is pumped up to tanks above the house that provide pressure via gravity. I've only ever used the springwater during a bad drought. Glad it is there though.
>Heating
fireplace
woodfired oven
electric blankets
I live in Australia, the winters don't get cold enough to run the fireplace except for a few of the coldest days of the year, the woodfired oven is what we mostly use as it provides cooking and hot water as well as heating.
>Hot water
gets its own mention
I have 3 ways of getting hot water
water jacket on the wood-fired oven
instant gas system
excess solar feeds into a hot water tank, 8 months out of the year we generate enough solar for this
>Cooling
ceiling and pedestal fans
>Septic
Aerated wastewater treatment system
backup: shit in a hole/bucket

>>2519243
I'll answer your 5, and then tell you the 2 most imporant considerations you're missing.

>Power
Solar. A properly sized solar system will power all your non-heat loads in winter, and in summer will give ample power for cooling.
You can go full /diy/ on this, you can buy everything brand new, or anything in between. If you use LiFePo4 batteries, the thing that will fail the soonest is the inverter-charger-controller. A system made with quality components can easily work for 20 years without problems, and longer if you buy some spares.
For backup power, a diesel generator. They will run off of all kinds of fuel, and are pretty easy to fix.

>Water
This greatly depends on your area. In my locale (Western PA), you could live off of catchment water alone. Other places will need a well or desalination method.
For storage, it's hard to beat a massive cistern in the ground. The water should be somewhat filtered before going in, and filtered again when coming out. You pump the water up into a tank in the attic to give you pressure. This pump can be powered by anything - solar, wind, a horse, you, etc.

>Heating
Wood/coal/straw/poo fired boiler heating a giant insulated hot water tank, which acts as heat storage. Traditional wood stove as a secondary/backup. Optional ground source heat pump can handle all your heating (and cooling) needs when there's enough solar power, allowing you to save your fuel for those very cold and dark days.

>Cooling
Proper location and passive construction will help with this. Building partly underground/into a hill will allow you to leverage the earth's constant temperature for a source of cool in the summer, and heat in the winter. No matter what you build, insulation is a must. Ground source heat pump is the best method of active cooling.

>Septic
Septic tank is ez, or you can treat it yourself by aerating the sewage in multiple stages. The resulting water will be clean enough to discharge direct.

cont. Part 1/2

Part 2/2

While OP's 5 things are important to our modern life, he's missing two critically important considerations:

>Location
>Food

Location will influence virtually everything else. Trying to live off grid in the middle of the desert will be radically different than living in the southeastern US, which will be different than living off grid in the north.
The ideal location will have ample water, minimal risk of disasters, arable land, and climate that's not outright hostile. It's also important to consider the people living nearby, because you will have to interact with them, and they will affect your life.

Food is of utmost importance. You could have the perfect setup to take care of OP's "Big Five", but if you don't have a way to grow food, you're going to be at the mercy of the economy. Grow energy rich foods like sweet potatoes, corn, etc, and raise chickens + goats for meat, eggs, and milk.


I personally don't believe there will be any kind of "collapse" or "SHTF" in the way that doomers dream about, as that would essentially require every country on earth to get carpet bombed by nukes. That said, I understand the desire to live free of a system which seems to actively discourage any kind of self-sufficency.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2522445
>i don't understand having to pump septic tank
Over time, a septic tank will fill up with "non-digestible" material.... All the organic matter breaks down, with some of the resulting compounds being CO2 or methane etc that is volatile and will exit the system, or with water soluble compounds that will leach out through as effluent. But ultimately, some material will remain.

Eventually, you have to pump or dig this material out if you wish to continue using the system. On a reasonably sized system, you shouldn't need to pump it more than every decade or so.
There are estimates about the volume per person per year which will slowly fill the tank due to solid human waste alone, and other estimates which take toilet paper and other product usage into account as well.

You want to draw the air that the fire consumes and sends up the chimney from an exterior source. If it draws from inside the house then the windows/doors will have to leak in cold air to replace the air that is consumed for the combustion of the fire.

Ideally you want your buildings to have positive pressure so that the windows and doors will leak out air instead of leaking in air.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2521269
I'm still confused about how either direction of air leaking makes any difference in terms of ambient temperature.

If I have my intake to pull in inside air where cold air settles and is the coldest jn my house, and it creates negative pressure and thus pulls in additional cold air, that cold air settles in the same place and continues to cycle out of the house because of the position of the intake.

If I pull air from outside and create positive pressure, not only is it taking 10x longer to heat the coolest parts of the house because the stove is effectvely doing nothing to circulate the air inside and relying on radiant heat in the one area that it can heat, but im then also causing the air I have heated to leak out of the house.... Then also factor in the idea that you have an additional hole in your wall where outside cold air will conduct into the room through the intake pipes.

I think in theory the exterior air intake only works in thermally homogenous, spaceship-level airtight spaces where there arent any strange thermal systems to account for. My house is old and has large open rooms among 3 stories. I can have cold air being sucked in from my windows in the lower level while hot air rises and escapes through the top floor. Theres alot going on that I cant control without copious amounts of money and time.

I think it all comes down to whether you want to evacuate cold air from inside, or only create hot air. With an outdoor intake I could have 10 stoves burning and still have a cold lower level/basement because the hot air will just rise and escape from my top floor, exactly like it does now.

You only need full double wall when pipes are too close to an unshielded interior wall or other combustibles. Otherwise just using a double walled insulated exit chamber in roof or wherever your pipe exist the home is fine.

I have inherited 8 chairs with varrying degrees of damage. See picrel. I asked craftsmen for a quote, they want ca. 250 €/$ per chair. This is not acceptable! (Poorfag)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524432

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524432
Replacement generally has to be done the way the chair was originally done, if it used mat than you use mat, if it was woven than you weave it. Mat is simple, like replacing window screen but when it starts to fail it goes quickly. Woven is more work, a little cheaper and if a strand or two breaks the chair will generally not care much. So rip the cane completely out of one and see if it has holes or a groove. Order the supplies and have at it, expect a chair or two to be failures before you get the technique down. If you are weaving then I would get a book, having those nice color photos well arranged with descriptions of the process well arranged and laid out for you to reference while you work will be very helpful. Most libraries should have a caning book or a chair making/repair book or a canoe making book (canoes often have woven cane seats so your butt can dry out). Videos will suck for this since you will find you need to jump back and fourth a lot. You should be able to do all 8 for less than what that guy was charging for one, but you should also be able to find someone cheaper to do it, try upholstery shops. Caning chairs is enjoyable and not a bad skill to learn. Personally I prefer rush seats.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524445
Weaving a chair seat is not difficult and does not require much in the way of tools, some tapered dowels, something to soak the can in, something to cut the cane with, about it. Matting is fairly standardized, don't need manufacturers ID or anything here, if you want it the same then you just measure the cane size and order mat of the same, sold by the yard.

>>2519137
I have made a few hunting cabins and guest houses using timber framed cob with adobe/lime plaster. They work really well for the summer and okay for winters. The only thing to watch out for is leaving the sills unprotected/untreated like in my first pic. You also need to know before hand where you are going to hang up heavy objects and plan appropriately. Cob isn't very good for holding heavy objects, but you CAN carve into the walls and make indents for holding items.
If you live in a really cold climate, I highly suggest looking into haybale homes because they insulate a lot better due to being thicker. No, bugs aren't an issue as long as you pack the bales with clay and plaster them properly.

What these anons are referring to is titanium's nasty tendency to work/strain harden. When you bend/deform a piece of material, you expect it to get weaker, right? Not titanium. When you bend, cut, or drill into titanium, it gets significantly stronger. All ductile materials do this to some extent, but titanium gets SIGNIFICANTLY stronger in strain hardening than pretty much everything else.

Also, what's with the influx of wildly underqualified people on here trying to make armor? The last guy ended up looking like a paper mache action figure. Are you preparing for the dipshit brigade? You should give up on this entire idea and do something else, it's several degrees of magnitude harder than you think it is.

Yes, I have one (1908 model 15, though the manually driven table top one. These go to for $10-30 because they are antiques but not rare and too heavy for most people. You fix them up with rust remover, vinegar and sewing machine oil and itll run fine BUT if the machine was ever dropped, or bumped into something, the main shaft for the needle or the camshafts on the bottom may have damage, it won’t turn well, and there’s almost no way to straighten them. So only buy one that ‘sort of’ runs when you buy it. Also most have no reverse nor any of the helpful features that help when you’re still learning.

Citric acid, the powder form. Make a bath out of some with water and soak your iron for a couple days. It reacts with rust to create chelate, which wipes off easily.
Rub it with oil to protect it afterwards.

posts.sub: Solar Power: Building new home to be as off-grid as possible.
posts.com:
Already using the system on our current house. installed it all ourselves. we generate about 40% of our power. running since March.

we have 2 load panels (breaker boxes) in our house. one is original, one installed by us. the one we installed is SOLAR ONLY. the two DO NOT CROSS in any way. our solar load panel is 100% off-grid. no grid-tie.

this powers 40% of our house. the rest is on grid.

when we move into the new house we are building, we will expand solar system. our aim is to be self sufficient in two to three years. house should be complete in 3-4 months.

current array is 2440 W. we have 8 FLA batteries wired 4s2p. running on a Sol-Ark 12k charge controller inverter.

upgrade will include switching to LiFePo4 batteries. 3x Fortress Eflex. we will add more as cash flow allows. we live debt-free, so no financing.

this powers:
2 chest freezers
2 refrigerators
air handler motor
70" TV
PS5
bath lights
hall lights
living room lights
entire guest room
vent hood
dish washer
outdoor outlets
kitchen outlets
island outlets
gas range electrical (fan etc)
garage outlets
garage door opener
garage lights

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2523337
>Is magna sine a good company
It's made by Magnum, and they are regarded to be a pretty great company for this stuff. They have lots of clear specs, good technical support, they're made in the USA (Everett Washington) and the owners and some of the engineers for the company are active in some of the solar power forums where they will candidly and helpfully talk with customers. They also have all kinds of accessories and stuff so you can run all one brand if you want to.
Same with Outback honestly. Some of their employees have worked for Magnum too-- they're also located in Washington state and IIRC the owner of Outback formerly founded Magnum or vice versa.
>For low consumption power... chest freezer, lights, radio thats it, should i tend towards 48v battery bank to minimize inversion loss, or 12v, to maximize amp hours?
If that's literally all you will be running then you'll be fine with 12v and it will be cheaper with 12v. Where 48v really shines is when you want better efficiency when running large loads in a larger system. If this is a system that you think might eventually grow and be expanded upon, then you might consider future proofing it a bit by going 24 or 48v from the get go. Obviously your inverter is 12v, so it makes sense to just start with what you've got.

>Is there any reason not to clip the stupid connectors and just use wire nuts?
You can use wirenuts if you want to, but the MC4 connectors are waterproof and convenient. IDK what problem you're having with them?
>How big of a deal are in line fuses between panels and charge controllers?
You should be using appropriate fuses where needed. If you really only have 2 panels like you describe, you CAN just run them to 12g romex, but romex isn't weather resistant. Not using a fuse is like driving in a car with no seatbelt.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2523337
If it was me, I would sell the 2812 inverter and buy a much higher capacity 48v inverter from Magnum, Outback, Victron or similar (for about the same price) and then use the Outback 80 charge controller to be able to support a much larger array. But it doesn't make sense to do that unless you want to expand the system.

That Outback80 can support ~4000 watts of solar panels if you use it in a 48v system compared to the ~1000 watts at 12v.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2523337
>or 12v, to maximize amp hours?
This is a meaningless question. Amphours don't do anything for you. A 48V 50Ah array has the same storage capacity and output* as a 12V 200Ah array, except the 12V is much less efficient due to losses in wiring and inversion. The only reason to use 12V is if you are making a very small, very cheap system, or you already have existing components.
*the power output can actually be lower on 12V depending on the battery technology and specs.
>>2523340
Do the wiring and protection like in the specs. Don't do stupid shit if you don't want to ruin your expensive electronics. Buy a $10 crimping tool for MC4.

>>2524000
>>2523997
This

Regular consoomer 120V stuff isn’t going to be above 15A/1800W because that’s the limit of a regular house outlet and dumbasses would be grinding off part of the plug and starting fire.

Therefore the 2000W 120V heaters are going to be more industrial quality and lower quantity production than the common cheap 1500W heaters. If you only have one 20A circuit to play with, get a 1500W and a smaller one or keep the second at a lower setting.

Also you should do some testing. Is the shop a seperate building? So you have a double pole 20A circuit in the main panel, then that runs to the shop, and you have a 3 single pole breaker in the shop? If this is the case, then you have more like 4800W capacity, maybe you have those two 15A single pole breakers coming off one pole of the 20A double pole in the main panel, and the second pole of that 20A double could be going to the 20A single pole at the shop.

Take a pic of both panels. If you have a 2 pole 20A breaker wired to the shop, then you should be able to run 2x 1500W-1800W heaters at full blast assuming you get them on different outlets tied to different breakers.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>2524026
The pics are all 404’d

But this is 4chan, so take every response with a grain of salt.

But double pole breakers mean you have 240V, it’s two different 120V live lines on different phases. So go live to neutral on each of them with a meter and it will be 120V, go live to live between them and it will be 240V. That can get split back down to two different 120V circuits when it hits the shop.

I mean if you really want to test it, get an extension cord and a multimeter, plug the extension cord into an outlet at one end of the shop, bring it close to an outlet at the other end of the shop. Then take your multimeter set to AC volts, and stick one probe in each of the live slots like pic related. If you get ~240V, the outlets are on different phases and each one should be able to handle its own 15A heater. If it reads ~0V, or it reads ~120V between the live of the outlet and the N of the extension cord, then it’s on the same phase and I’m not going to tell you how it’s wired for sure.

posts.com:

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>2524046
Do the test with the meter and extension cord. If you get 240V between the hot and hot of two different outlets, you should definitely be able to run two 1500W-1800W heaters, one on each of those outlets at the same time. I can’t see shit from those pics as they’re all 404’d and just thumbnails.

If it’s a 20A double pole breaker at the house and that all goes to the shop, it means you probably have 4800w potentially at the shop. If there’s a box in the shop fed by that 20A 2 pole, and that shop box is 2x 15A single poles and 1x 20A single pole, I’m going to guess you have that 20A double pole broken back up, one of them going to the 2x 15A and one going to the 1x 20A breaker for different circuits. But you should get the meter and cord, because you could have one of those poles off the double pole going to garage doors or lighting, not outlets, and have all the actual outlets on the other pole, which only leaves you 2400W across all the actual outlets.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>2524046
Maybe pic related helps explain it. That 20A double pole breaker going to the shop means you have a 240V 20A circuit running out there. And then it gets broken back down into different 120V circuits at the smaller panel in the shop.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524050
>because you could have one of those poles off the double pole going to garage doors or lighting, not outlets, and have all the actual outlets on the other pole, which only leaves you 2400W across all the actual outlets.
how would i determine if this is the case? thx for the help im gonna go poke around after dindin

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>2524052
Do the thing i said here >>2524033

Plug an extension cord into one outlet, and then find an outlet on the other side of the shop. Grab your multimeter (You have one, right?), set it to AC Volts, and plug the red lead into the smaller slot (hot) on the outlet, the black lead into the smaller slot (hot) on the extension cord that is plugged in across the room.

If it reads 240V, that means each of those outlets is on a different phase like shown here >>2524051 so each of those outlets is def going to be on seperate breakers and the shop can handle two heaters on those two different outlets.

If you get 0V on that multimeter test, there’s a good chance those outlets are all on the same breaker and might trip it running 2 heaters.

If there’s numerous outlets in the shop, test a couple different ones and see if you get 240V between any of them.

>the type of gear to be made
>the material you want to make the gear out of
>the gear's size
>the number of teeth
>and so on

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2514282
Depends on the type of gear and the tooth profile. For simple spur gears the best options are shaper and horizontal milling machine. A vertical mill could also do the job, but the set up would be a bit awkward and a lot less rigid than a horizontal. In all cases you need an indexing fixture. For milling processes you would need to purchase the correct cutter for your desired pitch. With a shaper you just need a single point tool, which you could probably grind by hand.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524049
an arbor holds a tool like a slitting saw or a woodruff cutter. a mandrel is just something that goes inside of something else. there are expanding mandrels that are threaded and increase in diameter when you turn the screw in. they also use mandrels in forges to weld pipe around.

Last Threadhttps://boards.4channel.org/diy/thread/2514198#bottom:

All the info you need about 3D-printing: https://pastebin.com/AKqpcyN5
>Your print failed? Go to:
https://www.simplify3d.com/support/print-quality-troubleshooting/

If that doesn't help you solve your print problems, please post:
>A picture of the failed part
>Printer make & model
>Filament type/brand
>Slicer & slicer settings

>What printer should I buy? [Last updated 2022-11-19]
Under 250 USD: kingroon KP3L, Sovol sv01, Creality Ender 3 (v2), Anycubic Mega S
Under 500 USD: Qidi X-One2, Creality CR-10, Anycubic Vyper, Prusa Mini
Under 1000 USD: Prusa i3, Bambu Labs X1
Over 1000 USD: e3d toolchanger, Ultimaker, Qidi X-CF Pro, Build your own Voron, Rat Rig, Prusa XL (lol enjoy the wait)
SLA: Anycubic Photon, Elegoo Mars, Prusa SL1, Formlabs Form 3, Creality HALOT-ONE
Instead of buying a new printer, you could consider building your own: https://reprap.org/wiki/

>Where can I get free things to print?
https://www.thingiverse.com/
https://thangs.com/
https://grabcad.com/
https://google.com/
https://printables.com/
https://www.yeggi.com/

>What CAD software should I use?
Variants of professional parametric CAD programs such as Solidworks (lol paying for software), Fusion360, Inventor, Onshape, TinkerCAD, and AutoCAD may be free depending on your profession, level of piracy and definition of ''free''.
Most anons use Fusion360, but some /g/oobers prefer OpenSCAD or FreeCAD. If you want to do mesh free-forming and modeling, Blender is alright. Also while not necessarily a design program, Meshmixer (free) can be extremely useful for tweaking models to print.

it's risk management.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2517641
>what's the point of running a .6mm nozzle?
A 0.4mm nozzle can print layers up to 0.3mm tall. A 0.6mm can print layers up to 0.45mm thicc. But it's not just time saved by printing thicker layers. You can also cut down on the number of perimeters since the thicker the nozzle, the wider it will extrude. Obviously this all comes at the cost of fine detail, but IRL, it's pretty fucking hard to tell the quality difference between 0.4 and 0.6.

>>2517641
Printing with a wider nozzle will also create stronger prints. Prints are basically layers of plastic string lightly molten together, they delaminate relatively easily. A wider nozzle means the "string" the print is made from is wider, which is more rigid (because you need less layers).
