posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2518043
Two things
1) clean the plate and don't touch it with your fingers the oils decrease adhesion
2) turn your hotend and bed up to printing temp, send it home an all axes, so you should be at Z0.0 then go into your movement menu and raise Z by .2mm (or whatever distance you have a matching shim for) then whip out your 0.2mm shim and level with it until the shim just barely drags under the nozzle when perfectly flat against the bed. Do every corner (well not actually the corner, best results are directly above the screw your adjustment knob turns) in sequence, twice.

Now your set up so that when your slicer tells your print head to move to Z0.16 or Z97.82 you will be exactly that distance, not a slip of paper off of those distances.

With this done you will have less trouble figuring out / calibrating other settings in your slicer like initial layer height and flow.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2518043
Forgot to ask what machine you are using? The ender 3's and some other printers have a Z Axis screw on one side of the bed and mere rollers on the other side so it just kinda hangs or sags, which isn't so bad cause your bed levelling will compensate for it being out of square (not really but your layers can still be parallel with the bed because you've levelled the bed to be parallel with your gantry arm in all its sagging out of square glory). It's pretty easy to either have the rollers on that floating side be too loose or too tight.

If too loose it gets floppy but still kinda usable. It'll burn out the Z stepper faster tho.

If too tight it can be an issue if it's also dirty by causing it to be a little stubborn. If there is debris on the column or stuck to the wheels it will occasionally require a slightly larger movement to get past the crap that's in the way of the rollers, this leaves your print head slightly higher or lower than it should be. This is a big deal unless your laying down some thicc .5 mm layer heights with a big phat nozzle. Occasionally stubborn z movements on normal layer heights will ruin your repeatability and causing poor adhesion sometimes but not others. Try cleaning the column and rollers, give the roller bearings a little shot of lubricant if they aren't sealed. With a finger gently apply a small lifting pressure to the floating end, if it moves easily it's too loose. Adjust as needed. It's better to be a little too tight than a little too loose.

so the green is bound by the red "skin". when i do the first inside green wall, it spreads out further than it ought to. the line is wider than .4mm or whatever.
then when i do the next "outer" green ring, the nozzle melts some of that previous extra wide line and as the plastic is extruded, it displaces the previous line upwards slightly.
like you could imagine a trough and you're laying a bead in the center, the liquid plastic isn't going to be compressed, the nozzle is going to melt the outer walls a bit and the new bead is going to force the outer walls up slightly.
and i think that means that each layer is not flat. its flat with some raised spots in between each line. and that error is carried upwards through each layer.
even though the next layer starts exactly where it should vertically, the lower layer has more plastic than it should, and that propagates upwards.
do you get what i'm saying? i don't know if this is right but it's what seems reasonable.

>>2518743
You need to compile your own Marlin. There's a setting in the source code for how many points to probe, you can probably probe hundreds of points if you feel like wasting time. Honestly probing nine points is fine for 200x200mm, I use that on my Ender and it's fine. Creality use sixteen IIRC.
It's not as bad as it sounds, but I haven't done it in years because once you have a working firmware you basically never want to touch it again. If you have an older printer you can open the Marlin source code in the Arduino IDE, make your changes, and flash it to the printer directly. If you have a newer printer you need to use VSCode with some extension and compile into a binary on your computer. You then need to open the hidden folder it for some reason saves the compiled file to, copy that to your SD card, and restart the printer with the card plugged in. It'll automatically flash the firmware. You can verify by plugging the SD card into your PC again and checking if the firmware file changed name, if it did that means it successfully loaded.
Hope that helped.

Can't remember which of you was having issues with wonky layer widths resulting in weird overextrusion problems, but go find a 3D model test print with a name something like "0.4 mm wall test" or whatever. The model should be a squat box with no bottom and no roof - just the walls exactly .4 mm thick or just choose one that matches your nozzle width. Check your print settings and make sure line width is set to exactly match. Print. Measure. Then adjust your flow until it's printing walls within .02 of the line width in your settings. Don't measure the elephant's foot, ignore it or print on a raft for these test prints.

.01mm usually accepted in printer settings but not really. Ender 3's only let you, while at the machine, manually adjust the height in increments of 0.1mm but even that is stupid.
Most steppers on printers have 200 steps in one rotation and z screws of a particular pitch so the single step resolution is 0.04mm so all your z-height settings should be a multiple of that for most consistent results but some motor/controller combos apply partial voltages to achieve partial steps. Good luck

>>2519000
Marlin is a repo you download from github. In it are folders with premade configs for a whole bunch of printers, unless you bought something super weird there'll be a premade config for your printer there. Copy the config files from the template folder into the actual folder (github has instructions somewhere IIRC) and make the changes you need/want, then compile.
https://github.com/MarlinFirmware/Marlin Marlin repo
https://github.com/MarlinFirmware/Configurations Premade configs
https://marlinfw.org/docs/basics/install.html Marlin official documentation
Arduino IDE can do 8-bit control boards, PlatformIO can do any control boards. If your printer updates firmware via SD card you want PlatformIO, otherwise you want Arduino.

3D printers sit on that intersection between DIY and mechatronics where you're expected to both be reasonably handy and tech savvy enough to handle compiling stuff. Use the repos I gave you and figure this out on your own with Marlin's official instructions. Don't go on reddit and download premade configs/firmwares, 99% of the time whenever a user "tunes" their printer they've actually just made it worse and they're only confirmation biasing themselves into thinking it's an improvement. Companies like Creality are full of idiots, but the people actually designing these printers are usually themselves printing enthusiasts, see Prusa or Timaz (behind the scenes guy at Creality). I'm not particularly clever but I never had any problems updating my firmware for adding a bltouch to my Ender 3, I'm sure you'll figure it out too.

>>2519985
Why are you printing on a raft? That's 2005-era cope, back when all we had was ABS and extremely warped aluminium beds. Bottoms on rafts are basically always going to be shit, you're printing a mm away from the actual layer of plastic to ensure the result is easily removable, but as you can see the result looks like garbage.
Print directly on the glass with skirt (you want to extrude just before the actual print starts, to make sure you have pressure in the nozzle), use brim if you absolutely cannot find another way to get it to stick. Try hair spray before you resort to brim though, brim should be your last resort.

Print at 100% flow rate, and lower your z offset until you get good squish. See pic related. What bed surface are you using? If you can't get it to work with just glass and hair spray, try washing the glass thoroughly with soap and hot water, and try different brands of hair spray. You only need a little, just spray back and forth in a zig zag quickly.
If you absolutely can't get that to work, try painter's tape. Go to a hardware store and buy the widest blue masking tape they have, and just cover the bed in a single layer. Make sure it wraps around behind the glass for a centimetre or so, and then strap the glass down to the bed of the printer with binder clamps. Let the bed cool down to room temperature before you try removing the prints, and each application of tape should last a few prints at least.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2520407
If you have a printer with auto leveling it should be somewhere in the firmware. Google "printer name z offset".
If you have a printer without auto leveling you don't need z offset, just adjust the print bed height with the adjustment wheels, or if you have to, move the z sensor up or down.
If you absolutely must adjust z offset in the slicer, Cura has a plugin to enable this feature. Open market place, find and subscribe the plugin, restart, open settings, scroll down to Build Plate Adhesion, enable Z Offset, close settings, open slicer settings and set z offset to whatever.
The cura option is meant for people who switch between for example PLA and PETG frequently and don't relevel their printers between them. PLA likes to be squished but PETG prefers having a bit of extra distance, so the z offset option exists to let you add 0.1mm offset for your PETG prints. Unless this use case applies to you it's best to just make sure your printer levels properly to begin with rather than add an extra step.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2520005
Auto level printers aren't magic. The bed probe eliminates the need to do fine adjustments on the bed level, but it can't do all the work. You still need to level it manually once to start off, so the bed is perpendicular to the gantry of the printer, and you need to adjust z offset because of manufacturing differences in the probe and the hotend.
Make the printer home z and then unlock the x and y motors so you can move it around by hand. Z should remain locked. Adjust z offset until sliding a piece of paper beneath the nozzle meets with a little resistance. Now move the nozzle to each corner of the bed and slide the paper under it. Adjust the wheel below until you feel about the same resistance as you did at the center. Repeat in each corner. Apply a bit of hot glue to each wheel to lock it in place semi-permanently, this way the vibrations of the printer working won't make it uneven. Now start a test print. Compare to >>2520010 and fine tune z offset until your first layer looks perfect. Save to EEPROM.
There, done. From now on auto leveling should handle things on its own. It'll compensate for things like gantry sag on printers with only one z axis rod, or random stresses on the frame slightly twisting it over time. As nozzles wear down over time you'll need to adjust your z offset. Same when you install a fresh nozzle. If you knock the printer around you may need to do a new manual level. If you switch to a new filament or build surface you will probably also need to adjust your z offset. All auto leveling does is remove the tiny intermittent level adjustments you need to do to compensate for vibration and wear.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2520503
Your manual level doesn't need to be perfect, I just think it's just nice to do things properly. What matters most is your z-offset, like you say the ABL will compensate for a warped bed. Did your first layer look like the centre of >>2520010? When it lays out corners on the first layer, does it look as if the plastic sticks immediately or does it sort of "curl up" or get dragged along by the nozzle? In my experience PLA that's getting good adhesion can do 90 degree bends flawlessly at 30mm/s on a heated bed. Subsequent layers you can probably knock that up to something like 100mm/s if you have an XY-style printer, or about half that for a bedslinger like your Ender clone.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2519934 #
Generally, 60 to 120% is acceptable. A lower width produces finer detail and a larger width produces better strength. IMO 80% is a good compromise and helps balance strength and detail.

What works FOR ME is I run a 0.5mm nozzle and leave most of my slicer settings as if I was running a 0.4.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2520940
That's a good idea, and I'm probably going to do something similar. Another advantage of using a bigger nozzle is that if you're printing troublesome filaments, for example with metal or wood effect, or just have crappy quality hardware store PLA, it'll be far less likely to clog.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2520645
Any filament cooled in my nozzle will ooze, PETG worse than PLA I think. And since it's oozing it kind of sticks back and makes a loop on the nozzle. Before auto leveling the nozzle purges and if it's stuck at the end will make a loop. I'll gently disengage then after the purge wait two seconds and whip the purge off.

After the auto level it will pause again and often the nozzle will ooze some more, like a few mm. The few mm is the only thing a skirt needs to then clear and it's usually not looped back. Sometimes I'll pull the ooze bit off too before it starts.

So if you've got a hanging purge or ooze and it doesn't get trapped in the skirt, try adding passes to your skirt or doing a brim. if the skirt brim isn't sticking use gluestick. but I think probably making yoru skirt 3 loops or something will give it more opportunity to dislodge before the print proper starts.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2523698
I have three Creality printers and they've all been great.

I think the problem here is that Creality are probably the biggest printer manufacturer in terms of volume sold. If we imagine that all printers fail at an equal rate, you're going to see more "My Ender is broken" than "My Anycubic is broken" simply because for each printer Anycubic sell, Creality sold ten.

That's not to say Creality are necessarily the same quality as more expensive brands, they're still a Chinese brand targeting the low budget market, but you do get a pretty decent printer. Sturdy aluminium frames, actually high quality hotends and nozzles, dual gear extruders are standard on the newer models, etc. Yeah you're not getting an E3D direct drive hotend, you get Creality's plastic bowden extruder and Creality's PTFE hotend, but the print quality is still plenty good enough and all-metal hotends are pointless unless you're doing nylon or other high temperature filaments anyway, and hardly anyone is. I've been printing PETG for ages, which most say is too hot for a PTFE hotend, but none of my printers have had any issues from it.

If you care about customer support, though, stay far away from Creality. If you do get a dead printer, I've heard that they are next to impossible to deal with. If you're in this hobby you're probably handy enough to fix whatever goes wrong, but that's not an excuse.

posts.com: The sad fact of the matter is that Creality actually has way above average QC. In fact when I have to buy replacement parts for my Creality printers I usually look for genuine Creality parts first, then the Aliexpress shit second.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2523965
Your actual issue probably isn't that the gears flatten the filament, but that you're doing too many retractions with too high spring pressure. Flat filament is simply the symptom.
Try turning on combing. Another option is to loosen your extruder spring. If it's already as loose as it can go, you can use wire cutters to shorten it. That makes you more likely to grind filament in the future, though, so it would be better to just fix whatever is causing your printer to feed the same length of filament back and forth enough to noticably flatten it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
What you are holding there is the cladding from an uranium fuel rod, most likely a souvenir from a decommissioned nuclear reactor. They are usually encased in a shielded container and only taken out for educational purposes, with appropriate protection, as they can still be quite "hot" for decades after removal.

Uranium is twice as dense a lead, that's why it is so incredibly heavy.

For proof, here's me holding one that has been decontaminated and is well intact.

Yours appears to be slightly darker in color and shows a significant amount of wear, which indicates that the chromium coating (the shiny finish) has started to erode over time.

This is not good, and you really do not want to hold that with your bare hands.


Are there any markings on it??

See that conchoidal fracture? That, my good sir, is probably elemental silicon. Probably a wafer-stock rod from a chip-manufacturing plant.
It's easy enough to test: Silicon is a semiconductor, so if you have a multimeter lying around your abode, set it on ohms and take a resistance reading between two close points on the surface. You should get a moderate resistance instead of nearly zero as you would expect for an actual metal.

>how
Mechanically or electrically.
Electrically will involve practically reprogramming the motor controller. While it is barely possible to reverse engineer the system, it's not at all practical.
The manufacturer, however, may already have a different firmware that does exactly this. Because if they don't already sell your unit to physical therapy offices, they probably sell a similar model with the same board. Write to them with an appropriate sob story. Or try to find someone who repairs gym equipment with same.
If the motor is not direct drive on the shaft, you may have a belt or chain to play with. Smaller motor gear to larger treadwheel gear means slower treadmill. But also higher torque, so make double sure your safety stops work.

The back and sides are melamine. It's a pretty shit product to pocket hole or attempt to screw with any kind of security. It's fine for nailer boards like mounting uppers with pan head screws. But there it's simply sandwiched between the screw and the wall.
If you attempt to pull things together by going into the melamine with a screw, it will tear out almost immediately. MDF even is much stronger.

I would glue up with silicone. This will hold until you decide to peel things apart again then can be scraped off. Most cabinets have a corner clip of plastic or wood and you simply screw up into the countertop. A bead of silicone across the top surface would be plenty here. It doesn't need to be a fancy caulk job.

Angle brackets will be fine as long as they have supports and not just L-brackets. Look for shelf braces.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You don't necessarily need composite if you get pvc with foam insulation in the frame channels. Things like low e glazing help (some people think they're a scam, I haven't made up my mind yet). Argon gas is also pretty standard these days but that dissipates.

Dual pane glass should be fine. Biggest thing is making sure it's installed right and knowing that if you do go with a purely vinyl window there will be sag down the line with operable windows.
As for the patio door a slider will always be less efficienct than French doors, but French doors are typically more expensive. If you go with French doors pay the extra for fiberglass as they are typically better insulated than steel, and steel dent/rusts/demlainates much easier.

You won't get anything quickly unless your shit is all whatever is standard sizes in bongland, and that's only for the door. There are no "standard" window sizes but you might get lucky and have your RO be close to sizes that manufacturers run in bulk.

Quickest fix is plastic wrap and blankets over the windows.

posts.com:
>>2522922
That shit is for decoration only, and it will get minced once you start using it, hence why it's sold in the fitness section, not the hardware section.
If you want something cheap, easy and effective, buy a carabiner and a U clamp. Tie a half knot through the carabiner, and then clamp the short end of the rope to the long end with the U clamp. Make sure that the U clamp has no sharp edges (could shear the rope; use sandpaper), and then tighten it properly (hard, but not hard enough to strip the threads).
It's easy to assemble, easy to attach to stuff, and the rope will literally break before that knot comes undone. I use it for spelunking and rock climbing, and it has yet to fail me.
>>2523149
>But what system is easier for a beginner?
See above. You just have to tie a half knot and tighten 2 nuts, it can be done in under 5 minutes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2523401
>crosby
I assume you refer to the half knot. I chose this knot for several reasons:
-easy to make in every condition
-easy to undo in every condition, should you need to (even if the rope is wet, frozen and you can't see)
-can hold onto the carabiner when the rope is not in tension (so the carabiner doesn't just slip out)
-can tighten around the carabiner when the rope is in tension
Also, this particular knot stays a bit loose when the rope isn't being pulled, which does 2 things:
-allows for adjustments according to need (if the carabiner is tethered at a weird angle, the knot can slip on the carabiner and match the weird angle, as opposed to having the rope stretch over a rigid knot, which wears out the rope faster)
-tightens around the carabiner only when needed, as opposed to having the knot keep the rope always tense (I'm referring to the bit of rope that the knot is made of). This prevents unnecessary wear and tear on the rope. Why does that matter? Let's say you've tethered yourself to a rock, and you need to readjust your position. The rope is loose, but the knot will still rub on the rocks. If the knot is somewhat loose, some of the fibers in the knot will get caught by the rock's jagged edges, but they won't break, they'll just stretch a little. If the knot is tight, those fibers can't stretch, so they'll tear. This isn't a problem initially, but if you do this for 2-3 years, the rope will get worn out, and you better hope you realize what's going on and replace your rope before it wears out too much to hold your weight.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2523401
>bowline
I don't really like this knot, because it's too rigid, it's difficult to undo it in unfavorable conditions, and because tensioning the rope pulls the loose end back into the knot, aka the knot gets undone with time. Maybe it would be useful for snares, but even then, the amount of friction prevents it from tightening quick enough. If you really want to use a knot that works like a bowline, then it would be better to tie square knot around a round object, and then pass the working end through the loop. Or at least tie a knot in the standing end of the bowline and then partially melt the very end to prevent the knot from coming undone.
>e-taping
No. That shit wears out too fast, it ages poorly, and the glue doesn't even do that good of a job at preventing the fibers from slipping (+ it makes an annoying crinkly noise every time you move it). The standing end will just get pulled from underneath the tape.
Tape is strong against extension forces applied to itself (not the glue), and it attaches well to clean, flat surfaces. It does a poor job against shear forces (applied to either the tape or the glue), and it has a lot of trouble binding to dirty or fibrous surfaces, like rope. That's why I suggested using a U clamp.

To be fair, your particular application may not require you to be as thorough as I have to be, but I think that if you intend to do something, you should go the extra mile to make sure that it's done properly, so that you leave as much room for user error and misuse as possible.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2521604
>the proper angle
Depends on the material to be drilled. It doesn't have to be perfect to work, but it does make a difference. There are references for optimal angles for different materials. The standard 118 degree point is decent for most things, while 135 is better for hard metals. Generally, the harder the material, the wider the optimal tip angle. I've used tip angles above 150 degrees for 300 series stainless. Regardless, don't twist or rotate the bit while grinding. Flat facets cut much better than curved, even though curved is the standard for store-bought bits.

> Seems like you need a jig to get consistent results.
Skillz. Or sufficient practice to get gud. It's a hand-eye dexterity task, and like others, people can get pretty good at it.

>Learn to sharpen by hand on a bench grinder.
This, but: Use a disc grinder instead.
I have pic related, and sharpening drill bits here works so much better than on a bench grinder, and you can do much more than just sharpening. I use 120 grit paper.
You can use the table to lay down your hands properly, and if you just move your fingertips to turn the drill bit to sharpen the other edge, you get much better symmetry than on a bench grinder.
I once sharpened a 20-pack of drill bits 1-10mm, took me under 15 minutes. I drill stainless steel often, and if something about my technique was wrong, I'd surely notice here. If the angles are a bit off, it does not matter for a home gamer, as long as it's symmetric.
As for the best drill brand, I found "Drill Force" bits from Aliexpress very convincing.

t. tool and die maker, Germany.

>>2521540
Drill bits are deceptively complicated to sharpen.
You have 4 main angles to hold perfectly at once, then you have to flip the bit around and do it all again to the same depth on the other side.

Every drill bit is different, the helix speed and flute geometry is different. It makes the angles at which you hold them wildly different.
Generic cheap jigs like that dont ever work
Drill doctors dont have the range of adjustment and work poorly for 75% of drill bits, and simply wont work with the other 25%.
Ive ran thousands of bits through a top of the line Darex XT-3000 and an M5 at a prior job.
I also own a 750X Drill Doctor.
The home versions are imprecise, weak, hit and miss with adjustment, the shitty wheel leaves terrible finishes, the chucks are plastic trash.
All in all, its jumping through a ton of hoops to try and do a precision job with a very flimsy non precision tool.

Dont waste your money, whatever people who are telling you its a wonder tool have no clue what they are talking about.
Sharpen by hand with a bench grinder. You can get dull bits to cut reasonably well with some practice and underlying understanding of drill bit geometry.

Find some GOOD videos on how to sharpen a drill bit (IE a machinist). Everyone claims to know how to regrind by hand, but there are tons of videos of people who clearly dont know what the fuck they are doing, ive bought used bits that were completely butchered by hand.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2521604
Muscle memory and using your brain. Its a skill you have to learn.
Use a tool post to plant your hand, never adjust your grip, move as little as possible.
If you actually know the angles you are trying to achieve, you can actually watch and see.
Youll know by sight how close or off you are and what adjustments you need. You can tell what face angle you are grinding at based upon where your chisel is clocked to the leading edge.

Reality is, for sloppy and rough work in wood and thin aluminum etc, your drill bit doesnt have to be ground well. Most cheap chinese bits come from the factory with bad grinds anyways
Its not that hard to get a bad but will still drill rough work grind by hand

>They don't have a parallel cutting edge in reference to the shaft. Making them useless.
Stepless bits are nigger rig eyeball shit, but you are fucking retarded.

The Irwin Unibit (the originator and still one of the best) started as a single flute and are still single fluted today for a reason. Lots are
The whole double and triple flute garbage is recent marketing nonsense.

The WHOLE IDEA of the unibit is to have a 0 or negative rake cutting edge, and to have the cutting edge supported on the parallel edge of the tool.
Thats the reason they are easy to control and produce such clean and accurate holes.

Have you ever wondered WHY regular bits cut triangular holes as you go bigger?
Because you are using a hand drill, and you dont have the physical strength to hold a large tool perfectly centered, while having two cutting edges fighting against each other. As you allow each edge to grab and release grab and release, it creates a triangle hole.

When you have a single cutting edge and 3/4 of the rest is a perfectly round hunk of steel, the edge is pushing against a form of the hole you want, its not going anywhere, its creating the shape and size you need.
Buy a 2 or 3 flute step bit, you are defeating one of the main fucking purposes of it.
